Yes, several countries are working on enacting regulations to monitor the usage of facial recognition technology. For example, the European Union's GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) has provisions that regulate the usage of biometric data, including facial recognition. The GDPR mandates that businesses and organizations inform the people whose data they collect and ensure that they give their consent beforehand.

In the United States, some states and cities have taken steps to regulate the use of facial recognition technology. For example, San Francisco has banned the use of facial recognition technology by city agencies.

However, in some countries, regulations are underdeveloped, leading to a lack of accountability, transparency, and oversight. It is essential to have robust regulations in place to address the ethical concerns surrounding facial recognition technology and to provide protection and privacy to individuals.
